title: The Outsiders
author: S.E. Hinton
focus: How Ponyboy reveals class structures he can't fully articulate
metaTitle: The Outsiders Annotation Guide (Free Download) - Social Lens Analysis
metaDescription: Download our free annotation guide for The Outsiders. Learn to identify class signifiers, social boundaries, and narrative perspective. Includes color-coded system and structured activities.

colorKey.name: Class Signifiers
colorKey.description: Objects showing group identity (hair, cars, clothes)

semanticFamilies.name: Class Signifiers
examples: Hair/Grooming: Greaser hair (long, greased) vs. Soc hair (clean-cut)
Vehicles: "Old souped-up cars" vs. Mustangs, Corvairs
Clothing: T-shirts, leather jackets vs. madras shirts, nice clothes
Cultural References: What movies, music, activities each group likes
semanticFamilies.keyQuestion: Does Ponyboy see these as class markers or just as "how things are"?

semanticFamilies.name: Social Boundaries
semanticFamilies.description: Physical and symbolic barriers between groups
examples: Geographic: East Side vs. West Side
Spaces: Where each group feels safe or unsafe
Crossing Points: What happens when someone enters the other group's territory
semanticFamilies.keyQuestion: Who controls access to different spaces? Who gets to feel safe?

activities.title: Mark Class Signifiers
activities.instruction: As you read, highlight or underline every object that signals whether someone is a Greaser or a Soc. Use the color code above or write "CS" in the margin.
activities.task: After marking, list 5-6 signifiers you found

activities.title: Find the Boundaries
activities.instruction: Mark every mention of places, territories, or barriers between groups. Use the color code above or write "SB" in the margin.
activities.task: What spaces are "safe" for Greasers? What spaces are dangerous?

activities.title: Catch the Casual Mentions
activities.instruction: Mark moments where Ponyboy mentions violence or danger in a casual, matter-of-fact way. His tone tells us as much as his words.
activities.task: Find one example and copy it here. What does his casual tone reveal?

activities.title: Spot the Gap
activities.instruction: Find a moment where Ponyboy shows us something he doesn't fully understand. There's a gap between what he sees and what a reader can understand.
activities.task: Example: When Ponyboy talks about his hair, he sees personal style. We see a class marker that makes him a target.

discoveryQuestions: What objects or details immediately tell you whether someone is a Greaser or a Soc?
How does Ponyboy describe the Socs compared to how he describes his own gang?
When Ponyboy mentions danger or violence, what is his tone? What does this reveal?
What does Ponyboy accept as "normal" that a reader might question?
Where is the gap between what Ponyboy sees and what he understands?
